Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Do You See What I See: Finding and Measuring Faults in the Internet

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Diagnosing network and network application faults remains one of the most challenging and frustrating aspects of using the Internet, particularly for non-technical users, but also for system administrators. A single VoIP application may depend on half a dozen protocols, and basic network access requires numerous network elements, from wireless access points to authorization servers, to function. On a larger scale, researchers have only anecdotal evidence of the most common network problems and their prevalence. This makes it difficult to use actual Internet experiences to improve existing protocols and implementations.

The project proposes a new architecture and system, "Do You See What I See" (DYSWIS), to automate fault finding in residential, mobile, enterprise and data center networks in a systematic, extensible and scalable manner: Using protocol state analysis and packet timing analysis, DYSWIS automatically recognizes when network applications are likely malfunctioning. Leveraging social network graphs, the system finds suitable and mutually-trusting friends whose DYSWIS application can help with finding problems. As necessary, building on a programmable network platform, NetServ, in-network nodes are instantiated and discovered. DYSWIS then attempts to determine the cause of the fault, leveraging network views of other nodes to improve its diagnosis, by remotely invoking active probes at the network, transport and application layer.

DYSWIS collects and aggregates statistics about faults and their resolution, allowing researchers and operators to see trends and determine common sources of problems. DYSWIS is designed to be extensible, so that new standardized and proprietary protocols and applications can be added selectively. The project explores how to scale DYSWIS to the Internet, evaluates its effectiveness, and extends it to use a programmable network platform.

The project enhances undergraduate and graduate teaching, involves undergraduates in research projects, reaches out to industry and standardization organizations, provides tools and large data sets to researchers, and offers a data gathering platform and data for the benefit of Federal and State telecom regulators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Home and small-enterprise networks now host as many networked devices as large offices and universities once did, ranging from Internet of Things (IoT) devices like thermostats and smart speakers to printers, laptops, smartphones and personal computers. Instead of just plugging in a PC into a modem, home networks now usually have one or more Wi-Fi access points, usually with network address translation (NAT) functionality. Network usage has moved from email and web pages to video, IoT and maybe even virtual reality, all of which are more sensitive to performance problems.

Unfortunately, with the increase in complexity, managing such home networks has become much more challenging. Computer vendors and Internet service providers usually do not know the home network structure and can offer limited help beyond suggesting to reboot devices and upgrade software.

In the project, we tackled all aspects of managing complex home and small enterprise networks. Our DYSWIS (Do You See What I See) effort re-enacts the human model of asking others whether they are experiencing the same problem, and then automatically suggests likely sources of trouble. Other participants in the DYSWIS community are asked to run test probes and report on the result, using peer-to-peer technology. We were able to show that such systems can diagnose most common network problems correctly and efficiently.

Wi-Fi networks often slow down mysteriously and temporarily. Their performance may be affected by other users in the neighborhood, sharing the same channel, or non-obvious interference such as baby monitors and microwave ovens. Our WiSlow system tries to identify the sources of Wi-Fi performance troubles, and can, in some instances, even pinpoint where the source of interference is likely to be. For example, the baby monitor may be located in the neighboring apartment.

Video has become the dominant use of the Internet in terms of bandwidth. Despite much higher home broadband speeds, YouTube and similar services are often still not as reliable as cable TV streaming, with the dreaded "rebuffering" icon appearing all to frequently. We wanted to better understand the impact of such impairments on human viewers, i.e., to characterize the quality-of-experience (QoE). Unfortunately, asking users for their experience is not feasible at large scale, and results are likely skewed by negative experiences. Instead, we measure objective user behavior, namely whether they abandon watching the video content, correlating it with rebuffering and video stalling, pre-roll advertising and changes in video quality. We also set up a monitoring site that allows third parties to compare the video performance of ISPs, both within the United States and internationally. The tool we developed plugs into the YouTube viewer on desktop devices, but is readily modifiable for other similar video tools and for mobile devices.

Home networks may not only malfunction, but may also attack other networks, often without the owner of the network noticing any problems, using denial-of-service attacks. For example, thousands of compromised cheap security cameras brought down parts of the domain name system in October 2016, but continued to function. Using an emerging Internet standards effort, the manufacturer usage description (MUD), we have developed mechanisms to automatically derive such descriptions by observing the behavior of IoT devices in the network, using machine learning techniques. These descriptions are then translated into firewall rules, implemented in a software defined network (SDN) controller, suitable for both small home networks and larger enterprise networks. These rules protect the devices against many attempts of compromise, such as remote login, and disrupt any unauthorized outbound traffic, e.g., used to launch denial-of-service attacks or to exfiltrate private user data.

The project has involved numerous undergraduate and MS students, training them in all aspects of network management, the Internet of Things and the importance of designing human-friendly networks. The results may influence standardization and have contributed tools for others to use.
